description.text:
This is a holder that you can use if you want to replace the Raspberry Pi Model B with a Raspberry Pi 3 in the original version of the FABtotum 3D-printer.

NOTE: Please be aware of that you have to cut away some plastic on the FABtotum to get the Raspberry Pi 3 to fit. Please be careful if you decide to replace your Pi with a Pi 3. And make sure to DISCONNECT THE POWER CORD before you start.

I recently read that FABtotum has a new version of their 3D-printer called FABtotum CORE Edition. It is powered by a Raspberry Pi 3 instead of a Raspberry Pi Model B.
As an owner of the original FABtotum I was very interrested to know if it was possible to retrofit a Raspberry Pi 3 to the original version of the printer. I read in their forum that it should be possible so I decided to try to do it.

It was possible, and it turned out to work great! It did involve some "modification" of some plastic wall within the printer, but it was not that difficult to do. I also had to create something to hold the Pi 3 in place, as the screw holding the original Pi could not be used (the screw used a hole in the Pi PCB which is not present on the Pi 3).

Printer:

FABtotum

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I printed it with a 0.35 mm nozzle, but I don't think that the nozzle size matters.

Additional parts needed:

Besides the 3D-printed parts, you need the following to mount everything together:

  • 2 x 16mm M2.5 machine screws
  • 2 x M2.5 nuts
  • 2 x 20mm M4 machine screws
  • 2 x M4 nuts
Instructions:

A complete description of how to replace the Raspberry Pi Model B with a Raspberry Pi 3 is available at http://lele.se/fabtotum

title: Anet A8 Power Supply 80mm Fan Case

description.text:
This casing was made by request and fits an 80mm fan that is placed on the power supply that comes with the Anet A8 printer. It's the big brother of this fan case http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1861403
I designed it in such a way that you can position it anywhere on the outside power supply grid. It also has two openings for the cable (bottom or left side).
I recommend placing the fan in the middle of the power supply letting the air escape from the top and the bottom.

I hooked up the fan to the 12V output on the power supply.

Please view the pictures for more details.

If you made one please also post a picture of your setup.

Thanks.

Leo

01.01.2017 - Attention:

It has been pointed out to me that Anet seem to have changed the type of power supply being shipped and it might no longer be the same as the one I have. Please make sure the dimensions (see picture) correspond to your Anet power supply before print!

Printer:

Anet A8

description.text:
Update:
I added a meshsmooth to the mask to get a rounder finish. Refer to the Simplify3d shot with the purple jack head in my photos. The beige Jack is the previous version (as printed in the current photos) and the purple head is the new, yet to be tested but promising meshsmoothed stl. Notice the difference in file sizes between the two.

This is a beautiful design but I had trouble with the mesh. As shown in the Simplify3d slice image, there were seam lines across the face in the mask version. The right side of that image shows my mesh, created by taking the one-piece head and slicing the back off to remake the mask.

The articulated hands are from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1809355

description.text:
Here is some alternative parts for the PCB Drill (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1846582) by Geminy_Studio.

First I create a new motor mount for a drill I had laying arount, and that can be found on ebay (http://www.ebay.fr/itm/Mini-Micro-Small-Electric-Aluminum-Hand-Portable-Handheld-Drill-Bits-0-8-1-5mm-/381008422307?hash=item58b5df25a3:g:vI4AAOSw-jhUJrGD). It's in the file mini driller holder.stl.

To avoid pain to add and remove motors' mount in the slider, I design my alternative mount a bit loose. With a few sanding, it fit easly in the slider.
I added a M3 hole to lock the mount in the slider.
So I also added the same hole in the slider itself, which can be found in slider with pin.stl.
I used a M3x20 screw and a M3 nylon nut.

I had hard time having the original Handle_clutch lock in the gear axle. So I created a new one, Handle_clutch_screw.stl, allowing the use of an M3 screw & nut to lock the axle.

comments.text: Nice...I like it :)
comments.author: Geminy_Studio

description.text:
These are a set of guides to help quickly and accurately paint facing arcs on wargaming miniatures. In many games the precise orientation of a model is important to determine questions such as whether or not it can attack back. These guides give a handy way to paint or mark the bases of your markers and indicate your intent. A variety of sizes are included to cover all the most common games and models. The parts are very simple and should print with no difficulty---supports, rafts, etc., are all unnecessary. The only note is that models may not fit if your printer's dimensioning is not calibrated reasonably well.

If you do not have access to a 3D printer, a Kickstarter is currently live to produce these at very low cost in resin. If you do have a 3D printer but would like to continue seeing more free designs, we would greatly appreciate you backing the campaign as well!

print_settings.Notes:: Hotbed plate was prepped with thinned PVA glue for adhesion. You may find that using a thin raft or brim directly contacting the support material is a necessity if you pursue aluminum build platforms, even with PVA. Other filament plastics might have better results, but PETG can be very picky about bed heat and surface. My strong suggestion, always, DO NOT print PETG on 100c heated bare glass. It will stick like a mad mother and you'll almost certainly lose chips of glass as I did. ALWAYS lay down a thin coat of PVA glue and run the bed temps very hot, and let the first layer airdrop onto it. Don't try to press into the bed, it will want to roll off especially if you scrape through your prep layer. A very light free fall works well for first layer on PETG.

title: Plotter Pen Holder For Robo 3D R1 Plus
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a plotter pen holder for the Robo 3d R1 Plus. It started life as an attempt to use the Robo as a PCB resist plotter, which sad to say wasn't as great an idea as I may have hoped. The accuracy falls short of far better options, although it does work and can be used for demonstration or educational purposes in that regard. This is more useful for plotting basic art for signs or decoration. It was designed to use a Sharpie Extra Fine Point marker, although I'm sure it would work well with any pen or marker with a similar diameter.

The holder works by clamping onto the front lower portion of your Robo 3D R1 Plus extruder assembly, right over where the "DO NOT TOUCH" warning sticker is at. It WILL damage the sticker, just so you know... it's pretty tight. To attach it, face the inner curved surface toward the extruder carriage and press firmly. It will slip over the curve of the extruder carriage and snap in place. To remove, slide it a little to the right and push forward on the upper portion of it, it comes off easily. The riser with the slot is meant to accept a standard stepper motor mount screw, to screw into the unused hole on the extruder motor, although the riser itself generally gives enough stability simply by pressing against the extruder motor mount bracket. Feel free to experiment with that.

If you damage your printer with this thing, you're doing something really wrong, it's all your fault, and you should have been more careful. I.O,W. Not My Fault and not this thing's fault. Know your printer.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The orientation of the object is meant to favor the pen holder for print quality, which naturally means that the bracket inner surface will need support, as well as much of the rest of the build. Feel free to explore different print angles, just bear in mind that support will be needed and can be a bear to remove if printed in a not so optimal way. I used PETG on my personal copy, because I love the strength of it, but I imagine PLA would work fine as long as downforce isn't excessive. I experienced some slight warping in portions of the curved part of the bracket, but it didn't affect functionality, just a little bit of appearance. Removing support material from the inside was a bit challenging, and I ended up using a spiral cutter bit on a Dremel to clean away the remaining chaff firmly stuck to the middle inside of the bracket curved area. I used Simplify 3D with the following settings.

Filament ESun Black PETG
Speed 60mm/sec
Layer Height 0.2mm
Extruder Temp 225C
Hotbed Temp 100C with 1/8" aluminum plate taped over my damaged glass
Support Material Density 40%

Hotbed plate was prepped with thinned PVA glue for adhesion. You may find that using a thin raft or brim directly contacting the support material is a necessity if you pursue aluminum build platforms, even with PVA. Other filament plastics might have better results, but PETG can be very picky about bed heat and surface. My strong suggestion, always, DO NOT print PETG on 100c heated bare glass. It will stick like a mad mother and you'll almost certainly lose chips of glass as I did. ALWAYS lay down a thin coat of PVA glue and run the bed temps very hot, and let the first layer airdrop onto it. Don't try to press into the bed, it will want to roll off especially if you scrape through your prep layer. A very light free fall works well for first layer on PETG.
I use Elven magic.

description.text:
This is a yet to be completed enclosure for a Makerbot Cupcake controller.  I see it using a relatively powerful microcontroller, some tactile buttons, "nokia knock-off" display from sparkfun, and some tactiles.  Preferably have it tap into the power of the makerbot motherboard.
Sketchup file is provided for additional hacking! :)  Enjoy!

The STL files provided do not have holes provided since there is no circuit board design reference provided yet.  I am hoping that this will inspire others to continue the development of this device.
FrontPanel - Probably would contain the cutout for buttons and lcd display.
RearPanel - Attaches to front panel to conceal internals.
TactileButton - This was designed to be the buttons which should fit over generic tactile buttons.

description.text:
This base prevents the motor from bending at an angle toward the base. The motor will try to angle outward due to the weight on the motor and the base's lack of support. 
This part attempts to resolve the problem by adding a 2.3mm wide lip so the motor has nowhere to move. 
A 2.3mm lip should work with all nema 17 motors, and I know for sure it should work with the ones Lulzbot and Ultimachine sells.

description.text:
I set myself the design brief of utilising the lip on my fish tank for seedling germination during the winter months. There's plenty of light, warmth and humidity.

These small pots are open bottomed allowing for the easier extraction of the seedlings once germinated. The excess water drains in to the trough but no further. I would advise printing in ABS but I have printed in PLA with significant success!

The trough itself has arms designed to latch on to 6mm glass/ perspex to try to prevent accidentally knocking them in to the open tank. There is also a slightly larger lip on the front (fishtank facing side) to help prevent individual pots also being knocked in.

I have mostly used these to germinate cactus and succulent plants. If you have success with any others then please let me know in the comments below.

Feel free to ask suggestions/ suggest design improvements.

Tesfurdo

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I try to print closer to 200 for PLA because this creates a better seal between layers to try and limit any potential water leaks which would be bad for the fish tank.

I used a Printrbot Simple Metal... not sure why this isn't an option in the drop down list I had to select from after selecting the manufacturer.

title: 3D printed kinetic Servo clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Somewhat based on, or inspired from, the excellent Plotclock (thanks Joo : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248009), here is my kinetic servo clock !

See it working here: https://youtu.be/nNygre-98G0

Motion is obtained from two RC servos whose arms are connected in a W shape. At the middle of the W sits a screw able to push the minutes arm via a pad. The minutes arm itself can push the hours arm ...

An ESP8266 embeds all the needed software to make it a "smart clock" ! The ESP8266 is a wifi based microcontroler that can be easily programmed from an arduino IDE as if it where an arduino. The clock being connected to the internet (it is an IOT smart clock) it can get the time from an NTP server.
The clock is then able to automatically set the arms at the right time, move the arms every minute and perfom the adequate maneuvers to keep the arms in the right position.

it is then really fun to see it doing its mesmerizing job. I must admit it is also a bit noisy, but so fun that you will forgive it!

Obviously you need to buid an ESP8266 board, but this is a oiece of cake if you follow these step by step video instructions : https://youtu.be/Az-O-sgUcjM

The software is provided in the files section. Sorry some comments are still in French. some explanations are given here after...
Enjoy !

Printer:

aerostock

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

everything is printed in PLA

Bill of materials
  • some black and white PLA
  • 2x M3 screws; Length 1 cm
  • 2x M3 screws. Length 2.5cm
  • 7x M3 nuts
  • a piece of bike inner tube or any flat and thin rubber
  • 2x GWS pico servos (or any other but you'll have to adapt the support!). Distance between the two servos axis shall be 14cm sharp!)
  • one ESP8266 ESP-07 board
  • 14cm of 4mm carbon tube (or any other material such as aluminium)
the clock arms axis in details ...

positionning the clock arms by the servo and robotic arms is based on:

  • independancy of the 2 minutes and hours arms. When the minutes arm is moved the hours arm stays in its position unless they both come in contact.
  • friction that will allow each arm to be moved when a small torque is applied, but force them to stay in position to avoid any rotation under gravity or vibrations...

This friction aspect was the most critical to achieve. I ended with the following design (see macro picture):

  • punch a small hole into a piece of bike inner tube then cut around the hole a one cm round piece so that you end with a rubber washer. Cut two of them.
  • insert one inner tube washer into a 2.5cm M3 screw
  • insert the minute arm
  • screw a M3 nut and tighten it until there is enough friction to move the arm and keep it in position when gently shaked
  • deposit a tiny drop of CA glue to secure the nut and let it dry
  • once dry, insert the hours arm
  • insert the second washer
  • screw another nut and do the same tightening and gluing process

Et voilà, you're ready

getting started with the arduino ESP8266

to upload the firmware into the ESP8266 you'll need to be familiar with arduino IDE environment. There are plenty good explanations on the internet. jsut seach for "arduino ESP8266).

Assuming, your envirnment and board are both ready to operate you should ne able to open the source code file and compile it.
Uploading the firmware can be done two ways:

  • either by a serial upload using for instance a bluetooth JYMCU serial port. You'll need to do this way when programming the board for the first time. When done, open the serail monitor under arcuino IDE and note the IP address of the board allocated by your internet router and displayed by the firmware.
  • or by the OTA (Over The Air) method.. When the ESP board has been programmed , you noted the IP address of the board. just open a browser and type in the address the IP address + ":85/update" (something like 192.168.0.71:85/update). and you should see an OTA webpage opening (see picturehere after)... more explanation again on the internet (search for "ESP8266 OTA")
firmware users manual ...

Basically there is nothing to modify in the firmware except few parameters to trim.
The dedicated line are all marked with a "<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<" pattern. let's see all of them:

Wifi settings :
this is the first thing to do, type in the name of your wifi network and the associated password
const char ssid = "mywifi"; //<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
const char password = "mypassword"; //<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

calibration:
before inserting the clock arm axis you should calibrate the servos.
uncomment the #define CALIBRATION line, complie and upload the binary.

The servo arms will move every 5 sec from fully horizontal to fully vertical (down pointing).
Adapt the servo left and right null values to get the arms horizontal...

The SERVOFAKTOR LEFT should stay egal to 1.0 but there is also a possibility to trim those values if needed...

// delete or mark the next line as comment if you don't need these
//#define CALIBRATION // enable calibration mode <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

// When in calibration mode, adjust the following factor until the servos move exactly 90 degrees
define SERVOFAKTORLEFT 1.00 //<<<<<<<<<<<
define SERVOFAKTORRIGHT 1.00 //<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

// Zero-position of left and right servo
// When in calibration mode, adjust the NULL-values so that the servo arms are horizontal/vertical
define SERVOLEFTNULL 48 // expressed in degrees (between 40 and 55) <<<<<<<<<<<
define SERVORIGHTNULL 55 // <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

Timezone settings :
I had to adapt the Timezone library (credits and thanks to Jack Christensen) to make it work with ESP8266 (I suppressed the EEPROM management with was specific to AVR). The modified library is inlined in my source for simplicity.
To get the right time according to your location you'll have to define the timezone and the rules for time change. More detail in the source :

// comment/uncomment here after the time zone definition (2 lines) adapted to your location <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

//US Eastern Time Zone (New York, Detroit)
//TimeChangeRule myDST = {"EDT", Second, Sun, Mar, 2, -240}; //Daylight time = UTC - 4 hours
//TimeChangeRule mySTD = {"EST", First, Sun, Nov, 2, -300}; //Standard time = UTC - 5 hours

//Central European Time Zone (Paris)
TimeChangeRule myDST = {"CEST", Second, Sun, Mar, 2, 120}; //Daylight summer time = UTC + 2 hours
TimeChangeRule mySTD = {"CET", Last, Sun, Oct, 2, 60}; //Standard time = UTC + 1 hours

That's basically all you have to modify, but feel free to update anything !

comments.text: I've been thinking about making this clock, and decided to do a simulation of it.  From my simulation, it looks like the bielle.stl arms that are contained in the files are too short.  I measure them as 85mm between axes, and this seems to be too short.  It looks like they should be about 92mm.  Measuring the arms in the pictures seems to confirm this.  Is there a problem with the stl file, or have I calculated something incorrectly?
comments.author: regnaDkciN

comments.text:
Well, your measurements are correct. if you open the .scad file you get this :
h =2.5;

entre_axe = 85; <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< entre_axe is the distance between the two axis...
l_tete = 20;

comments.text: Thanks for the quick response.  From your spreadsheet I can see where my problem is.  I was using 47mm for the diameter of circle around the face, while you are using 40mm.  With this change, my simulation checks OK.  Thanks again.  I may be making this soon.

description.text:
I bought some cheap push fittings from china. Of course, they took months to arrive. In the mean time, I created this simple clamp. You slide the tube through the top hole and then clamp it with an m3 bolt and lock nut. This is meant to be used with the compact bowden extruder by tech2c because the height is correct. Simply mount this in front of your bowden extruder, and enjoy cheap, bowden printing!

Please note, I had to clean up my print with a soldering iron, because the clearance is tight, and my printer can be a bit sloppy. the hole diameter is 4.3mm, yet it still gripped the tube extra tight.

title: MM-CNCs moveable bowden extruder V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: With this extruder you can keep your bowden tube very short. Combined with the orientation of the filament spool, the preshaped/precurved filament from the spool can stay in its curved shape, because it is the major shape of the whole bowden tube.

After real good experiences with my moveable bowden extruder, I made the next release of this awesome piece of mechanics. I never had such a increase in quality. I'm now able to extrude & retract ABS @ 100mm/s. This reduced all the blobs & strings dramaticaly.
Not everything is printed in one piece. Some parts need to clued together, this keeps it modular and you can customize it to your personal needs.
Any questions are very welcome and will be answered as soon as possible.
http://youtu.be/PUIY7e32O-s

author: OLBA3D

description.text:
This disk is designed to be placed behind the stove-top knobs while not in use to prevent accidently activating a burner with catastrophic concequences.

I own a Samsung oven which was inadvertantly turned on (unknowingly) and the burner heated a pyrex bakeing dish (9x13) wich exploded sending shards of heated glass flying off the stove after being heated by said burner. This ruined my new vinyl flooring which had just been installed.

This disk has a slot to allow dropping in behind the knob without the knob being removed, works like a charm, will not allow the burner to be turned on without removal.

The holes have 7mm of diameter at the bottom to hold the piece against the frame of the car and 12 mm diameter at the top to allow you to pass the screw until the bottom and allocate its head.
I didn't have any issue to install it, but may be you should set the infill higher than 60% to incrrease the strength of the part.

I hope this is useful for somebody else

title: Linear motion 8mm axis and 10mm axis (rostock mini)

description.text:
I have a rostock mini myself and was unhappy with the stock linear motion system. The lm8uu bearings that i use are cheap and have a lot of play and you will see this in printresults clearly.

I decided to challenge myself to come up with a way to have a tight system, whilst having adjustable screws to tighten or loosen when needed. So here it is!

I have included a body for 8mm axis and for 10mm axis, since these are most used with LM8UU or LM10UU.
The Idler.stl is compatible with both. You need 2 pieces for 1 body piece.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Rostock Mini Ruby

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

Doesnt matter

Notes:

Most of this model is made of walls or perimeters. If your printing width is too large it may 'delete' certain important parts of the print.

I have printed in the current orientation since my cooling settings are ideal and luckly dont need any support.

My settings where:
0.15 layerheight
0.35 perimeter width (to ensure details remain good)
20% infill (there is not a lot of infill, mostly perimeters)

Before assembling

You need 36pc of 623zz bearings to make a kit of 3 linear rails like the rostock. You will need 36 screws or axis to satisfy these bearings. You should not need any washers.
To attach the idle piece to the body I took a screw of M3x40 and let it screw its own thread in the plastic. No nuts needed.

Before heading into full assembly-mode you should try fitting 1 piece and see if the 623zz bearing rotates freely. It cost me a lot of time to realize i had made a mistake early in the prototyping, needing to remove all 36 pieces a couple of times... something with donkeys and stones... ;)

title: Luna Lovegood Wand - with Core
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This all started when I wanted to print the fantastic wand that was designed by brycelowe but wanted to print it broken up vertically, and rather than having to stick the pieces together, create some sort of screw fitting........but what is a wand without a core?!

In true Wizarding World fashion, I have created a wand where you can print whichever core has picked you! Why not try....

A cherry red dragon heart string
A pearly white unicorn hair
A golden phoenix tail feather

This wand is printed in 4 parts. A handle, a central section, a tip and a core. The core is used to hold all the other 3 sections together, and remains hidden inside the wand. The core can only be revealed by unscrewing the tip and removing the central section.

After a request I updated the handle with a 4 petal design as produced by brycelowe. There are 2 files available; the handle on its own (so anyone who has already printed the wand can update it), and the set of all 3 parts.

Update (14-Dec-17): After a request, I extended the wand to be screen accurate to 33.25cm in length - see the file 'luna wand_extended 3325'. The Original core size will fit in this new wand. Enjoy!

WARNING: Always ask permission of the wand owner before revealing the core - it is magical after all and can be temperamental. Unfortunately, we can not be held responsible for any spells back-firing.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The wand_core will need to be printed with a raft, the other files can be printed without.

All printed in Faberdashery's fantastic PLA:
Ginny Weasley Wand - Woodland Brown
Luna Lovegood Wand - Desert Tan
Elder Wand - Earl Grey
Dragon Heart String Core - Cherry Sour
Unicorn Hair Core - Pearly White
Phoenix Tail Feather Core - Bling Bling Gold
Elder Wand Core (created by death himself) - Smoky Black

Assembling Your Wand
  1. Screw the core into the handle
  2. Slide the central section over the core
  3. Screw the tip on to the end of the core

description.text:
The old original attraction icons at Epcot (sans the Health Pavilion). Not practical like TheNewHobbyist's coaster set, just something to decorate a shelf (and collect dust).

Since I made these 3D, I took some artistic liberty; hopefully I stayed true to the original designers' intent. And, because these don't have a base, I had to add some connectors as the design would otherwise be disconnected (such as with the World of Motion, or the Universe of Energy).

Printer:

Maker Select (Wanhao Duplicator i3)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

10

Notes:

Infill isn't needed, especially if it's just decoration. Since it is decoration, a low resolution is recommended, but it's totally up to you.

Just found some black and white images of the original logos, brought them into Sketchup, started by just eye-balling the size, but then doing as much precision work as I could while sticking to the original design.

Blender was then used for Boolean operations. For example the Epcot logo was actually five tori (I had to look up the plural of torus), rotated from the center of the logo at 73 degree angles, so there was a lot of internal geometry that needed cleaning. The free version of sketchup doesn't have great of boolean tools, so I just used Blender.

Then I just used my imagination to 3D-ize them, such as The Land sloping upwards like it's growing plant; or the Living Seas being wavy because... well they're waves.

title: Support for filament cleaner and lubricator

description.text:
I designed and printed this part since I had frequent problems with PLA printing.
My extruder got bloqued several times and I read somewhere that by lubricating the flament with kitchen oil, you might solve the problem.
This fact is certainly working for me, and I guess it might help other makers to correct similar problems.
You have to screw the part to the metal frame of the front of the printer, cut a little piece of sponge and place it inside the housing of the part. Then make a hole to the sponge in the middle making sure that your filament will pass correctly (I used the own filament to make the hole) and get lubrified when you will fill it with some kitchen oil. For this I use virgin extra olive oil as it is common in my region :) and it works perfect.

IMPORTANT NOTE: If you are going to print a part taller than 10cm, you MUST unscrew this sponge support from the frame of your printer, since the extruder assembly will crash with it when going high.
It happened to me once and the temporary solution I found was to unscrew it and stick it with some adhesive tape to the upper part of the extruder while this printing finished. Then I screwed it back to its place.

A pearly white unicorn hair
A golden phoenix tail feather

This wand is printed in 4 parts. A handle, a central section, a tip and a core. The core is used to hold all the other 3 sections together, and remains hidden inside the wand. The core can only be revealed by unscrewing the tip and removing the central section.

WARNING: Always ask permission of the wand owner before revealing the core - it is magical after all and can be temperamental. Unfortunately, we can not be held responsible for any spells back-firing.

UPDATE: I have also included an extended version of this wand which makes it accurate to 15 inches. You might want to check it fits on your print bed as the height of the print is 154mm.

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Supports:

No

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The wand_core will need to be printed with a raft, the other files can be printed without.

All printed in Faberdashery's fantastic PLA:
Ginny Weasley Wand - Woodland Brown
Luna Lovegood Wand - Desert Tan
Elder Wand - Earl Grey
Dragon Heart String Core - Cherry Sour
Unicorn Hair Core - Pearly White
Phoenix Tail Feather Core - Bling Bling Gold
Elder Wand Core (created by death himself) - Smoky Black

Assembling Your Wand
  1. Screw the core into the handle
  2. Slide the central section over the core
  3. Screw the tip on to the end of the core

Some people have reported issues with the slender top of the middle section having a split. This occurs in the slicing software. A quick fix is to scale the design up to 125% (as long as your printer can handle the height!). Just don't forget to also scale up your core so that everything fits together nicely.
Alternatively, try printing this version:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2418915

title: Simple Replicator enclosure, no laser needed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: We where looking for a simple enclosure for the replicator 1 without the need of a laser but couldn't find anything satisfactory. So here is my solution derived from multiple sources.

We printed all parts out of PLA with 0.2mm Layer height.
Except for the cornes, those we printed out of Laywood, but you can use PLA too.
The parts for the top frame need support we used PVA as support material. I've included our custom profile for makerware, that worked pretty well. PVA seams to print better when it is warm.
The right knob needs support too.
The PDF files contain the dimensions for the acrylic panes. We used 4mm panels becuase we had that laying around.
I've also included a step file of the complete construction (including the RPi housing) so you can change any dimension in there. You need to print the following things:
Inside corners:
1x Air intake
1x FanDuct
2x CornerPlug
1x Keypad_Cover Bottom windows:
2x Hinge_left
2x Hinge_right
4x hinge_top
8x Panel_clip
1x Knob_left
1x Knob_right
1x Knob_right_latch Top corner covers:
2x Top-left_corner (goes in front left and rear right corner)
2x Top-rightcorner (gies in front right and rear left corner) Top frame:
2x Back_holder
1x Cable_cover_top
1x Cable_cover_bottom
4x Corner
2x Front_holder
2x Side_holder
4x Leg You also need the following:
16x M3 bolts
17x M3x10 screws
9x M3x6 screws All screws except the ones for the hinges can be screwed directly into the plastic and there is no tapping required. The parts for top frame clip into each other, but a drop of glue helps. Also the panes need gluing into the frame if you want to be able to lift it of of the Replicator. The left pane is designed to hold the RaspberryPi housing with camera hole. If you don't want to mount it, just leave the two holes in the middle away. UPDATE 22.11.13: We realized, that the hinges made of PLA don't last that long. It is better to print them out of ABS.

comments.text: 3DPrintClean is developing an Odor and Ultrafine Particle filtration attachment for DIY enclosures. Would make a great addition. See http://3dprintclean.com/3dprintclean-scrubber.htm - Disclosure, I am the founder of 3DPrintClean.

author: premerek

description.text:
A frame brace/support designed to give a single plate Prusa i3 extra stability and support at the join between the Y axis and the main frame plate.  
The brace can be retro-fitted to existing printers with very little (if any) disassembly.  
Note.  This will not fully stabilise the top of the frame like a full box frame version but will add additional strength and support to the lower frame while removing some flex from the upper frame.  
See Instructions for compatibility.

This brace is designed to fit a 6mm frame plate where the frame has a 2mm recess along the bottom edge (which I think is the standard prusa design). I also use the 4 holes along the bottom of the frame which I believe are intended for cable management(?) to secure the brace to the frame. I also suggest drilling a further 4 holes in the frame to secure the brace a the top, the best way to do this is to fit the brace and secure with the 4 lower holes and then use the brace as a template for drilling the upper 4 holes. Once fitted to the frame you clamp down onto the threaded rod with the bar clamps to complete the support. I suggest you connect the Y axis to the frame and align and tighten in the usual method before adding the braces. Parts you will need (note pictures show different lengths than suggested below)... 2 of printed frame braces
4 of printed bar clamps
8 of M3 x 20 cap head screw
8 of M3 x 25 cap head screw
8 of M3 lock nut
8 of M3 full nut
16 of M3 washer

This is a replacement lid hinge plug for a SULO bin (in Australia we call them wheelie bins). Our garbage collector makes a habit of driving over our bin lid and breaking the lid off the wheelie bin.   
Print with at least 25% infill and hammer it in with a rubber mallet to secure the lid back on your bin!
Print with standard settings, 25% infill, .2mm layer height. Doesn't have to be fancy; you're going to be hammering this into your bin hinge with a mallet!

title: Portfolio Solar LED Step Light in-ground stakes

description.text: This is a two-piece system for converting Portfolio solar step/deck lights as sold by Lowe's in a 5-light kit form into in-ground up-lights. The stake is designed to house the body of the light, the lens of the existing light is removed, the shade put in place, and the lens screwed back in. These work great as up-lights along a wall with garden-like soil. Do not expect to drive the stakes into well packed earth. I used them as shields for tombstone lights for my Halloween display.

remixed_from.title: intensewalkera Vibration dampening isolator mould - cast - template cylindrical form

title: intensewalkera GoPro Loveseat Vibration isolation mould - cast -template v2.2

description.text:
Revised to 2.2 - tab hole positions moved to allow better bolt access Revised to v2.1 a few minor tweaks , added a ribbed back, tapered a few edges to allow the silicone to pour in better. This is based on the team blacksheep loveseat , used on multicopters to isolate vibrations to the gopro camera range (will work with others). its a rough design, i will comeback and tidy up the design of this, once i get chance.i would like to have it hinged and free from none 3d printed parts. i.e lose the bolting up arrangement. http://youtu.be/OaK46BK0zEY bolt the two parts together with m3 bolts, don`t over tighten.
mix up your silicone and catalyst and pour.
i used 100g of rtv 2020 silcone/catalyst
checkout how to make the rtv silicone mix on google etc, there is plenty of info on there, you can see from my attempt, that i had too much air get in, this was totally my fault due to it being my first time using this silicone mixing. i know my next attempt will be far better, now i know what i am doing!
i used medium hardness silicone as a guess, i have not tested it in anger yet but i will get round to it shortly.
0.2 layer height with a high infil value to ensure the mould turns out a good quality finish

author: sonojojo

description.text:
50mm horizontal X Carriage with E3D v6 Hot end mount.

There is an E3D v6 fan shroud:

E3D v6 Hot end mount, Fan shroud (This has caused issues on TinkerCAD not able to upload files) and needs work, OK; too big a file but even if made smaller still fails to upload to TinkerCAD.

I've about given up trying to get TinkerCAD to upload for a fix.

have added two new files { Bigger Blow BLTouch Side E3d v6 Two Fan ring.stl and Bigger Blow Cable Side E3d v6 Two Fan ring.stl ). These have a deeper air ring design that should allow greater air flow round and through the gap in that ring. So why because you can turn air flow down, using PWM, but not increase it from the maximum. These two files have not been tested yet. These two Bigger Blow files made needed some work before 3D printing.

IMPORTANT!!! :-

This bearing block mounts to the existing bed plate holes as supplied by FolgerTech.

title: Centerpiece for Dipole / Doublet Antennas & Toroid Mount

description.text:
This is a centerpiece for double/dipole antennas, mainly for ham radio. It directly fits typical 4 - 10 m fiberglass masts and is ideal for portable operation & SOTA.

Features:

  • 2 vertical holes on the the rear which minimizes the load on the mast top section (other similar pieces have a simple hole, which can easily break the thin top section of typical masts).
  • Can hold a balun made of a T50 or T82 core (optional). The balun can either be mounted with a plastic M3x10 screw or a printable toroid mounting piece, which can be glued into the respective hole.
  • The connection to the transceiver can be built as either a piece of RG174 coax line or a BNC plug. The latter is better if you have multiple antennas, because you can then use a single 6 - 8 m RG 174 coax cable to the transceiver. The BNC plug is held by a separate printable mounting piece.

Strain-relief for the dipole arms and the RG 174 is done via 1.5 mm and 3 mm holes in the main piece.

Enjoy and meet you on the bands!

73s

Martin, DK3IT

description.text:
revised to v2.2- drip tray added to help prevent leakage. Bolting arrangement amended
Revisions v2.1- corner radius added to help prevent lift when printing, two end recesses added to allow the use of a screw driver to prise the templates apart. http://youtu.be/OaK46BK0zEY This is Based on the vibration dampening balls i already use , used on multicopters to isolate vibrations to the gopro camera range (will work with others). its a rough design, i will comeback and tidy up the design of this, once i get chance.i would like to have it hinged and a few other minor tweaks to make pouring the silicone in to the mould easier this is a version 2.2 the photos are the results of my v1 attempt, which came out well for a first attempt at moulding, but i modified the files a little, based on my first experiences. bolt the two parts together with m3 bolts, don`t over tighten.
mix up your silicone and catalyst and pour.
i used 50g of rtv 2020 silcone/catalyst as a guide of quantity checkout how to make the rtv silicone mix on google etc, there is plenty of info on there, you can see from my attempt, that i had too much air get in, this was totally my fault due to it being my first time using this silicone mixing. i know my next attempt will be far better, now i know what i am doing!
i used medium hardness silicone as a guess, i have not tested it in anger yet but i will get round to it shortly.
i printed with cura with a high %infil to ensure the detailed form was not lost. printed with pla and a layer height of 0.2.

author: intensewalkera

description.text:
I have included the thing files to help you with the way I ended up printing these (it took me 3 times to get a successful print of the left eye). I printed these at only 10% infill, with rafts and supports.

Basically I used string to tie these together at the top most eye holes and then to my glasses. Then I sewed string through the two top holes of the eyes onto my ski mask type hood.

OpenSCAD script to generate the polyhedron that is formed by extruding a polygon along a specified path. List comprehensions allow the path and polygon points to be specified parametrically.
Updated: added scale and rotate parameters for worm drive.

This now works natively in OpenSCAD.  The rotation algorithm has been implemented, including code to carry out rotations and produce numerical results. The polygon generation is also finished. The end join corner cases should now be fixed; see the basic path extrude script for a demonstration.
The Perl code that was previously used for doing this has also been included to show the history of the script / concept.

Pentagon spiral use <path_extrude.scad>; myPoints = [ for(t = [0:72:359]) [cos(t-18),sin(t-18)] ]; myPath = [[-1,0,0],[1,0,0],[2,1,0.5],[2,3,1.5], [1,4,2],[-1,4,3],[-2,3,3.5],[-2,1,4.5],[-1,0,5]]; path_extrude(points=myPoints, path=myPath); Double rotated spiral use <path_extrude.scad>; pi=3.14159; myPoints = [ for(t = [0:90:359]) [cos(t+45),sin(t+45)] ]; myPath = [ for(t = [0:3.6:360]) [5*cos(2*t),5*sin(2*t), (t<90)?0:((t-90) * 4*pi/180)] ]; path_extrude(points=myPoints, path=myPath); Trefoil knot I generated the the trefoil knot using mm1440's equation:
[ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:191895 ] use <path_extrude.scad>; myPoints = [ for(t = [0:18:359]) [cos(t),sin(t)] ]; myPath = [ for(t = [0:3.6:359]) [ 5*(.41*cos(t) - .18*sin(t) - .83*cos(2*t) - .83*sin(2*t) - .11*cos(3*t) + .27*sin(3*t)), 5*(.36*cos(t) + .27*sin(t) - 1.13*cos(2*t) + .30*sin(2*t) + .11*cos(3*t) - .27*sin(3*t)), 5*(.45*sin(t) - .30*cos(2*t) +1.13*sin(2*t) - .11*cos(3*t) + .27*sin(3*t))] ]; path_extrude(points=myPoints, path=myPath, merge=true); Double Helix use <path_extrude.scad>; shift=0; pi=3.14159; for(shift = [0, 360/15]){ myPoints = [ for(t = [0:72:359]) [cos(t),sin(t)] ]; myPath = [ for(t = [0:10:359]) [ (10+1.212*pi*sin(5*t))*cos(t+shift), (10+1.212*pi*sin(5*t))*sin(t+shift), 1.212*pi*cos(5*t) ] ]; path_extrude(points=myPoints, path=myPath, merge=true); } This is intended to simulate a right-handed DNA backbone with major/minor groove width of {1/3,2/3}, 5 turns per loop, 10 bases per turn, helix radius of 1/3.3 times the arc length of a single turn. The ring radius was 15 in this example. M16 Bolt see [ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_metric_screw_thread ] use <path_extrude.scad>; length=20; P=2; // pitch H=sqrt(3)/2 * P; // height of triangle R=H/(P/2); ppr=20; // points per revolution loops=length/P; D=16; xw=0.4; // extrude width myPoints = [ [-H/2-xw+0.1*R,-P/2+0.1], [1/4*H-xw,-P/8], [1/4*H-xw,P/8], [-H/2-xw+0.1*R,P/2-0.1] ]; myPath = [ for(t = [-(180/loops):(360/(ppr*loops)):360+(180/loops)]) [(D/2)*cos(loops*t),(D/2)*sin(loops*t), P*(loops*t)/360] ]; difference(){ union(){ translate([0,0,-xw]) rotate(180) cylinder(h=length+xw*2, r=D/2-3/8*H-xw/2, $fn=ppr); path_extrude(points=myPoints, path=myPath); translate([0,0,-7]) minkowski(){ rotate(180) cylinder(r=(24 / cos(30) - xw)/2-1, h=6, $fn=6); sphere(r=1, $fn=8); } } translate([0,0,length+D]) cube([D*2,D*2,D*2], center=true); } M16 Nut use <path_extrude.scad>; length=8; P=2; // pitch H=sqrt(3)/2 * P; // height of triangle R=H/(P/2); ppr=30; // points per revolution loops=length/P; D=16; xw=0.4; // extrude width myPoints = [ [-H/2+xw+0.1*R,-P/2+0.1], [1/4*H+xw,-P/8], [1/4*H+xw,P/8], [-H/2+xw+0.1*R,P/2-0.1] ]; myPath = [ for(t = [-(180/loops):(360/(ppr*loops)):360+(180/loops)]) [(D/2)*cos(loops*t),(D/2)*sin(loops*t), P*(loops*t)/360] ]; difference(){ translate([0,0,1]) minkowski(){ rotate(180) cylinder(r=(24 / cos(30) - xw)/2-1, h=length-2, $fn=6); sphere(r=1, $fn=8); } translate([0,0,-xw]) rotate(180) cylinder(r=D/2-3/8*H+xw, $fn=ppr, h=length+xw*2); path_extrude(points=myPoints, path=myPath); } Worm Gear use <path_extrude.scad>; myPoints = [ for(t = [0:12:359]) [3*cos(t-18),3*sin(t-18)] ]; myPath = [ for(t = [0:0.01:1]) [0 + 0.25*cos(5*t*360),0.25*sin(5*t*360),t*5] ]; myScale = [ for(t = [0:0.01:1]) 0.167*(cos(t*360)+1)+0.667 ]; translate([0,0,5-0.001]) cylinder(d=6, h=10.001, $fn=31); path_extrude(points=myPoints, path=myPath, doRotate=false, doScale=myScale);
Of course, native OpenSCAD code means that this path extrusion can now be animated: Animated Trefoil Knot

comments.text: The output of this should be fully solid if you have sufficient space between points in the 3D path, no big twists, and the resultant object is enclosed (merge=false for "free" ends, merge=true if ends are joined, but don't duplicate the first/last point).

description.text:
I made up this mouth based on my big head. It has holes in the back where the lips meet in order to run string through and then tie it to hold it on.

I printed it with raft, supports, and at 10% infill. This design makes it a bit tricky to clean out the supports from the holes. I ended up using a 2 mm drill and trying to get the material out so I could insert the teeth. The teeth were printed with the points down on a raft.

I then drilled a couple of holes through the placement for the tongue. (This is one area I could improve since I didn't take into account the curvature of the tongue loft when I made the cut.) So I cut the tongue with some wire cutters in order to get it to fit into the mouth groove. Using screws the tongue is secured in place. Superglue was used to keep the teeth in place.

description.text: The universal hands free soldering station that I have easily tips over. I designed this base to prevent the soldering station from moving, The retainer bolts to the base with an M3 bold and nut. Attach felt or thin layer of cork to the bottom to prevent sliding.

author: pava1960

print_settings.Notes:: The part has to be oriented with the plate, that the camera attatches to, on the Printbed.

title: x520 FPV Camera Mount Sony Effio 700TVL 1/3 2.1mm

description.text:
A mount for a 700tvl Sony EffioV FPV camera on a x520 Quadcopter Frame from xxl-modellbau.de or similar.

The camera is from Banggood.com (http://www.banggood.com/700TVL-FPV-HD-Ultralight-Camera-With-2_1mm-Lens-NTSCPLA-For-FPV-RC-Multicopter-p-1000385.html) and is quite okay for the realy low price.

Printer:

Zonestar D810

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Resolution and Infill is not that important. Use what you like.

The part has to be oriented with the plate, that the camera attatches to, on the Printbed.
I used Fusion360 to create the Model.
